DOC.HEAD: Report: Noriega Knew Attack was Coming
With AM-Panama Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega told an American lawyer that he expected the United States to invade his country, hours before U.S. troops attacked, New York Newsday reported Friday. A member of the law firm Slotnick & Baker met with Noriega to discuss publishing rights to his memoirs, which the now-deposed Panamanian leader has been writing for several months, partner Barry Slotnick told the newspaper. Noriega said he had completed a ``substantial portion'' of the manuscript, describing his rise to power through Panama's military and detailing his work for U.S. intelligence, Newsday reported. ``He realized his time was very short in terms of his ability to maintain himself in Panama,'' Slotnick said. ``He knew the Justice Department wanted him on trial; he was aware the United States was going to invade; he felt they wanted to kill or capture him.'' He said Noriega appeared calm during the afternoon meeting afternoon in Panama City. U.S. forces invaded at midnight Tuesday. Slotnick said no publishing agreement was reached. He said Noriega would not allow any U.S. company to publish the book or buy the film rights. The lawyer did not return a telephone call Friday.
